Check-in was fast and after that we were led to a first floor room by the bell-boy. The bell-boy got us crammed in a tiny elevator together with our luggage (not a five star treatment at all!). The room was quite nice and comfortable, but certainly not worth the price. The bed was very good and the linen high quality, but we noticed several stains on the carpet, covered up by various rugs and mats. Furthermore, the TV (a large flat screen one) was sitting on top of a small desk, so no workspace at all for writing. There was one armchair and one chair in the room and no coffee table. The bathroom was fitted with stunning Italian marble and had natural light, but it was quite small and we had to jump over the bidet to get into the bathtub. The bathroom amenities were cheap stuff and actually the shower cup and the vanity set boxes were empty. Also there was nothing complementary in the room when we arrived (not even a bottle of water), and for us this was very bizarre given that we had booked directly with the hotel and were paying a great deal of cash for less that a ten hour stay. Anyway, we had a good sleep and the room was quiet, but that was the least we expected. Breakfast was OK but not great, and pesonally I was amazed at the fact that the waitress ignored us all along. Upon leaving the concierge help us sort out a problem with our rail tickets in a very short notice, and this was the only moment of our stay when we felt we got good service. Overall, we did not hate this hotel but we were not very happy with it either. Next time we are in Rome we will stick with the St Regis, which a few months ago furnished us with an Imperial Room and excellent service for less money.

Reviews.Title: “Enjoyed this hotel”
Reviews.Author: tabbykins
Reviews.Content: We enjoyed a fine stay at this hotel. We did upgrade to a Junior Suite but what we were given I would rate as a full Suite. We had a spacious sitting room with seperate bedroom, linked by large double doors. We also had a large bathroom. I was delighted with our suite which was furnished with some fine antiques, a couple of pieces I coveted for my own home. I feel it is worth upgrading when staying in older hotels in Italian cities for the space provided. Although we do not plan to spend an inordinate amount of time in the room, I do enjoy having a sitting area to relax in. Excellent fabrics, linens, pillows & such a comfortable bed. Quirking plumbing though but hey, you're in Italy, it's usual! We did not eat in the hotel (other than breakfast which was very good) as we are familiar with Rome & have our prefered restaurants there. We found staff to be so helpful & our experience differed totally from last reviewer although we may have been there at the same time. We were prepared with restaurant bookings for every night but one which, due to our own inertia & indecision, meant we reached 7.30pm with nowhere to eat on a busy Friday night in Rome! No problem, concierge sorted us out & got a last minute table at an excellent restaurant nearly. Nothing was too much trouble for the people on the front desk, they are charming. The location of this hotel is excellent, not just for the shopping nearby, but only a modest walk to most things you are likely to want to see, including the Vatican. For longer distances, Spagna metro station is only a few steps away. The price I was quoted for a standard room was, by my experiences of Rome & given the standard & location of the hotel, cheap. I did peep into some of those rooms & whilst they looked beautifully decorated I prefer more space. For me the upgrade was worth it & when we return we will do so again. I can thoroughly recommend.

Reviews.Title: “Overpriced for what it provides”
Reviews.Author: PleaseDoNotDisturb
Reviews.Content: I would recommend this hotel only if you absolutely have to be within walking distance of the Spanish Steps and upscale shopping (but remember you can get to those places from almost any other hotel for a taxi ride costing less than 10 Euros). Our room was clean and well-appointed, although the bathroom was ridiculously small -- you could literally sit on the commode and rest your chin on the sink. The room was quite noisy from activity on the street below, which continued into the late evening. Staff were snooty and unresponsive. Lunch service in the restaurant moved at glacial speed -- we almost spent our entire trip waiting for the waiter to return to our table. The food was good, but not spectacular. We had difficulty arranging a dinner reservation at an outside restaurant because the concierge does not work on weekends! I guess they don't expect people to eat out on Saturday night. We asked the desk an hour in advance to get us a taxi, and when we arrived downstairs -- no surprise here -- there was no taxi. It was clear that they had never called for one, because one came in 20 minutes after they did place the call. We stood outside waiting for the cab that should have already been there, and then the doorman had the audacity to look at me for a tip when he opened the door for me! Next time, I will stay at one of Rome's other fine hotels for 100 Euros less, and take that 10 Euro taxi ride to the Steps. That way, I'll be 90 Euros ahead of the game when I go shopping.

Reviews.Title: “Wonderful low-key elegance”
Reviews.Author: rachilde
Reviews.Content: Relatives recommended this hotel but I was initially hesitant because of some of the reviews here. My fears were unfounded. We loved the understated elegance of the place. No, it doesn't have a traditional lobby, but rather several delightful public rooms. We got a great rate through American Express (290 Euros a night) that also included breakfast and tickets to the Borghese Galleries. The room was 50% larger than one costing the same amount in London two years earlier. The bathroom was large and luxurious with plenty of towels and amenities. The tub had an overhead shower and a handheld shower. The TV had internet capability for those evenings I didn't feel like walking to the internet cafe in the Piazza Barberini and the rate was reasonable (compared to what I experienced last year in Malta). Our room was buttery yellow. We noticed that each room is decorated differently. The buffet breakfast was fresh and delicious. They provide a variety of papers to read as well. The doormen and cleaning staff were very friendly and welcoming every day that we were there. The front desk people were efficient and professional. They were helpful with directions, lending umbrellas, etc. The neighborhood was well located for walking everywhere. Overall we were very happy with our stay.

Reviews.Title: “Hotel D'Inghilterra”
Reviews.Author: pauly789
Reviews.Content: My partner and myself went to Rome from 7 December to 10 December and were looking for a romantic, charming, slightly more traditional and nice hotel to base ourselves. Not only did we find this with the Hotel D'Inghilterra, the location is probably the best in Rome. From outside the hotel you can walk to the Spanish Steps in 2 mins and to the Colloseum, Forum and the Vatican within about 20-30 mins. The rooms were big, spacious and very clean and the marble bathroom is sheer opulence. The breakfasts were hearty and filling and certainly set you up for a day of sightseeing. The food in general was of a high standard and the bar served great drinks and the barman were very hospitable in always providing nibbles to accompany the drinks. The staff in general were friendly and we had no complaints in this regard. Whilst the hotel may be seen by some to be a wee bit expensive, deals can be done on the rooms and to be honest the price we paid was worth every penny for the location and the standard of the hotel. Highly recommended and charming!!

HotelInfo.Name: Hotel d'Inghilterra
HotelInfo.Address: Via Bocca di Leone 14, 00187 Rome, Italy
